title: jvanname
author: jvanname
content: Bitcoiners do not care at all about using cryptocurrency mining to solve an important scientific problem because Bitcoiners generally have very low levels of intelligence. In the past before 2017, Bitcoin was still a novel idea, so Bitcoiners on average probably had a higher level of intelligence. But now that Bitcoin has become more mainstream, it has attracted a lot of dumb people who know nothing. Now, it is really difficult to find a Bitcoiner who is intelligent enough to understand that Bitcoin's mining algorithm was never designed to advance science. Bitcoiners usually hate science very much because they are braindead doofuses.

comments.author: BADecker
comments.body: Well of course they care about the science. Just watch as they make enough money to start electrical power plants to further enhance their mining without hurting the people. Then they will start using the excess electrical power as another form of cryptocurrency, directly, without converting it to Bitcoin or an altcoin. Might not be your kind of science. But it's still science.

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: Harnessing mining power for other uses is something that has evaded people mostly. I’m sure if it were easily doable, we would all be mining to help whatever scientific cause is available. I suspect that merged mining could enable someone to build a solution to this problem, but so far I’ve seen nothing moving in that direction.

comments.author: iBaba
comments.body: Many Bitcoiners may prioritise the financial benefits of mining cryptocurrencies over the scientific purposes.  Although some Bitcoiners are more concerned with prospective financial advantages, others may be more  interested in delving into the technological breakthroughs and future applications of blockchain technology. For the time being, I don't believe the enabling atmosphere or platform is in place. But, of course, if we continue to debate such concerns and raise awareness, we will, sooner or later, begin to tackle problems in that direction.Hosting up conferences, symposiums, or forums to emphasise the benefits of mining cryptos to advance science will go a long way.

comments.body: You don't need to deeply know about mining algorithms to be a Bitcoiner. Probably you have your own definition of "Bitcoiner" ??People just order ASIC, plug it into the socket, configure a bit, and start mining. Same thing about GPU mining. It's basically plug-and-play without needing to know the technical behind the algorithm. Everyone with any educational background can mine, that's the beauty of this system. It's all the same with the wallet, private key, etc., now users are just to be users. I am pretty sure bitcoiners who are more on the development side already working on their thing, it will probably advance science if they are successful.
